children.text: In this portion of the interview, Arturo Ripstein recalls the reception of

at the San Sebastián International Film Festival (Edition 26), where the film—and particularly the kiss between La Manuela and Pancho—provoked intense backlash from both attendants and critics. Ripstein notes that the controversy extended beyond the screen: the director, actors, and crew were subjected to public scrutiny and hostility, revealing how the film’s challenge to sexual and gender norms exceeded cinematic boundaries and entered the realm of social offense.

This reaction must be situated within the context of late Francoist Spain, where censorship, moral conservatism, and authoritarian regulation of sexuality remained deeply entrenched, even as the regime approached its end. In this climate, the onscreen kiss was not read as narrative gesture or melodramatic device, but as a provocation—an intolerable visualization of queer desire that violated the tacit separation between what could be known and what could be publicly shown. The scandal underscores how
made visible not only transfeminine desire, but also the fragility of heteromasculine coherence when confronted with recognition.
